verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah a second time. This was while he was still locked up in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord, who made the earth, says, the Lord who formed it and who established it—the Lord is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Call on me and I will answer you. I will show you great and mysterious things you did not know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord, the God of Israel, says this concerning the houses of this city and the palaces of the kings of Judah (which were being torn down to build up defenses against the siege ramps and the sword
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: during the fight against the Chaldeans): I will fill them with the corpses of men whom I have killed in my anger and my wrath. I will hide my face from this city because of all its wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But watch! I will bring it health and healing. I will heal them and reveal an abundance of peace and truth to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cause the captives of Judah and the captives of Israel to return, and I will build them up as they were in the beginning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cleanse them from all the guilt they incurred by sinning against me. I will pardon all the guilt they incurred by sinning against me and by their rebellion against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will provide a name of joy, praise, and glory for me, in the presence of all the nations of the earth. They will hear about all the good that I do for this city, and they will tremble in awe because of the good and because of the peace I provide for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. You say that this place is a wasteland, without man or animal, and that there is no man living in the cities of Judah or in the desolate streets of Jerusalem, not even an animal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the sound of joy, the sound of gladness, and the voice of the bride and groom will be heard there once again. A voice will again be heard that says, “Give thanks to the Lord of Armies, for the Lord is good, and his mercy endures forever,” as they bring thank offerings into the House of the Lord. For I will restore the fortunes of the lands as they were in the beginning, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Armies says. In this place, which is desolate, without man and without animal, in all its cities there will once again be pastures for shepherds to rest their flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the Shephelah, in the cities of the Negev, in the land of Benjamin, in the villages around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, flocks will once again pass under the hand of the one who counts them, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will fulfill the good promises that I have spoken to the house of Israel and concerning the house of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days and at that time,
I will cause a righteous Branch to grow up from David’s line.
He will establish justice and righteousness on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days Judah will be saved,
and Jerusalem will dwell securely.
This is what she will be called:
The Lord Our Righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says.
David will never fail to have a man to sit on the throne of the house of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither will the priests, who are Levites, fail to have a man to stand before me to offer burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings, and to offer sacrifices continually.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. If you could break my covenant with the day and my covenant with the night, so that there would no longer be day or night at their appointed times,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: only then could my covenant with my servant David be broken, so that he would not have a son to reign on his throne. Only then could my covenant with the priests who are Levites, my ministers, be broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as the stars of the sky cannot be counted and the sand of the seashore cannot be measured, in the same way I will multiply the offspring of my servant David and the Levites who minister before me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you not considered what these people are saying—that the Lord rejected the two families that he chose? They despise my people in this way, and they do not consider them a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord says: If I have not established my covenant with day and night, or the ordinances of heaven and earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: only then will I reject the offspring of Jacob and of my servant David, and only then will I fail to choose one of his sons to rule over the offspring of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. So I will restore them from captivity, and I will have mercy on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, along with all his army, all the kingdoms of the earth, and all the peoples that were subject to him were fighting against Jerusalem and against all its cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord, the God of Israel, says:
Go to Zedekiah king of Judah and tell him this is what the Lord says. I certainly am giving this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will burn it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will not escape his grasp. You will surely be taken and handed over to him. You will see the king of Babylon eye-to-eye, and he will speak with you face-to-face. You will go to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even so, hear the word of the Lord, Zedekiah king of Judah.
The Lord says concerning you: You will not die by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will die in peace. Just as people made a funeral fire in honor of your fathers who were kings before you, so they will make a fire for you. They will lament for you, saying, “Alas, master!” This is my word, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah the prophet said all these things to Zedekiah king of Judah in Jerusalem
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when the army of the king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and against the cities of Judah that still remained, namely, Lachish and Azekah (for these alone remained from all of Judah’s fortified cities).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word came to Jeremiah from the Lord after King Zedekiah made a covenant with all the people in Jerusalem proclaiming freedom for the slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone was to free his Hebrew slaves, male and female. No one was to keep a fellow Jew in slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials and all the people who entered into this covenant agreed that they would set their male and female slaves free, and that no one would keep them in slavery anymore. They obeyed the agreement and set them free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after this they changed their minds. They took back the slaves they had set free, and they made them serve as male and female slaves once again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was after this that the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says. I made a covenant with your fathers on the day I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of slavery. I said that
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: every seven years you are to set free any fellow Hebrew who has sold himself to you. After he has served you six years, you are to set him free. But your fathers did not listen to me or pay attention to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, after you repented and did what is right in my sight, each of you proclaimed freedom for his neighbor. You made a covenant before me in the house that bears my name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but you have turned around and profaned my name. Each of you has taken back and enslaved his male and female slaves, whom you had set free to go where they wished. You forced them back into slavery, to serve as your male and female slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord says. You have not listened to me by proclaiming freedom for your brothers and your neighbors. So I am proclaiming freedom to you, says the Lord. Freedom to fall by the sword, plague, and famine! I will make you a horror among all the kingdoms of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to make the men who walked between the covenant pieces, but who did not keep the terms of the covenant that they had made in my presence, just like the calf they cut in two and then walk between its pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials of Judah and the officials of Jerusalem, the government ministers, the priests, and all the people of the land who walked between the parts of the calf,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand over to their enemies, to those who seek their lives. Their corpses will be food for the birds in the sky and the wild animals in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand over Zedekiah king of Judah and his officials to those who seek their lives and to the army of the king of Babylon, which has withdrawn from you. Watch, I will give a command, says the Lord, and I will bring them back to this city. They will fight against it, capture it, and burn it down. I will make the cities of Judah desolate so that no one can live there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord in the days of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the house of the Rekabites, and bring them into one of the rooms in the House of the Lord, and give them wine to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I took Ja’azaniah son of Jeremiah, son of Habazziniah, along with his brothers and all his sons—the whole house of the Rekabites—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I brought them into the House of the Lord, into the room of the sons of Hanan son of Igdaliah, the man of God. It was next to the room of the officials that was above the room of Ma’asaiah son of Shallum, the doorkeeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I set bowls of wine and some cups before the men of the house of the Rekabites, and I said to them, “Drink some wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they said, “We do not drink wine. Our ancestor Jonadab son of Rekab commanded us: ‘You are not to drink wine, neither you nor your descendants, not ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, you are not to build houses, sow seed, plant vineyards, or own any of these things. You must always live in tents. Then you will live a long time on the land where you live as nomads.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have obeyed what Jonadab son of Rekab, our ancestor, commanded us. We have never drunk wine—we, our wives, our sons, and our daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have never built houses to live in. We have no vineyards, fields, or crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have lived in tents, and we have obeyed everything that Jonadab our ancestor commanded us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon invaded the land, we said, ‘Come on, we have to go to Jerusalem to escape the armies of the Chaldeans and the Arameans.’ That is why we are living in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. Go ask the men of Judah and those living in Jerusalem: Will you learn a lesson and obey my words? declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab son of Rekab commanded his sons not to drink wine, and this command has been kept. To this day they drink no wine, for they have obeyed their ancestor’s command. But I keep speaking to you, again and again, and you have not obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have sent my servants the prophets to you again and again. They told you to turn from your evil ways, to reform your actions, and to stop following other gods in order to serve them. Then you would live on the land I have given to you and your fathers. But you have not paid attention or listened to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Jonadab son of Rekab have kept this command which their father gave them, but these people have not obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord, the God of Armies, the God of Israel, says. Watch this. I am going to bring down on Judah and everyone who lives in Jerusalem every disaster I have pronounced against them. I have spoken to them, but they have not listened. I have called them, but they have not answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said to the house of the Rekabites, “The Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says this. Because you have obeyed the command of Jonadab your father and kept all his instructions and done everything he commanded you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says that Jonadab will never fail to have a man to serve me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take a scroll and write on it all the words I have spoken to you concerning Israel, concerning Judah and all the other nations, from the day I began speaking to you in the days of Josiah until now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps when the house of Judah hears about all the disaster I am planning for them, each of them will turn from his evil ways. Then I will forgive their guilt and their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah called Baruch son of Neriah. While Jeremiah dictated all the words that the Lord had spoken to him, Baruch wrote them on the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah gave an order to Baruch, saying, “I am restricted from going into the House of the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so you will have to go. Read from the scroll you have written at my dictation. Read it in the hearing of all the people of Judah who have come from their cities on a day of fasting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps they will make a request to the Lord, and each of them will turn from his evil ways, for the Lord has planned great anger and wrath against this people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch son of Neriah did everything that Jeremiah the prophet had commanded him. He read the words of the Lord from the scroll in the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, in the ninth month of the fifth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah, all the people of Jerusalem and all the people who came from the cities of Judah proclaimed a fast before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Baruch read the words of Jeremiah from the scroll in the House of the Lord, in the hearing of all the people. This was at the chamber of Gemariah son of Shaphan, the secretary, which was in the upper courtyard at the entrance of the New Gate of the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Micaiah son of Gemariah, son of Shaphan, heard all the words of the Lord from the scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he went into the secretary’s room in the king’s palace. All the officials happened to be sitting there: Elishama the secretary, Delaiah son of Shemaiah, Elnathan son of Akbor, Gemariah son of Shaphan, Zedekiah son of Hananiah, and all the other officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah reported to them all the words he had heard when Baruch read the scroll in the hearing of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then all the officials sent Jehudi son of Nethaniah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Cushi, to tell Baruch, “Bring the scroll you have read in the hearing of the people, and come here.”
So Baruch son of Neriah brought the scroll in his hand and went to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Please sit down and read it to us.” So Baruch read it to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had heard everything, they turned to one another in fear. They said to Baruch, “We have to report all of these things to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They asked Baruch, “Tell us, how did you come to write all of this? Did Jeremiah dictate this to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch answered, “He dictated all of these things to me, and I wrote them with ink on the scroll.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials said to Baruch, “You and Jeremiah go and hide. Do not let anyone know where you are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put the scroll in the room of Elishama the secretary, and then they went to the king in the court. They repeated all of these words to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. After he took it from the room of Elishama the secretary, Jehudi read it to the king in the hearing of all the officials who stood beside the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king was sitting in the winter house (it was the ninth month), and there was a metal heating pan with a fire of burning coals in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Jehudi had read three or four columns, the king would cut it off with a scribe’s knife and throw it into the fire until the entire scroll was burned up in the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither the king nor his attendants who heard all these words were afraid. They did not tear their clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when Elnathan and Delaiah pleaded with the king not to burn the scroll, he would not listen to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, the king commanded Jerahme’el the king’s son, along with Seraiah son of Azriel and Shelemiah son of Abde’el, to arrest Baruch the scribe and Jeremiah the prophet. But the Lord hid them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king had burned the scroll containing the words that Baruch had written at Jeremiah’s dictation, the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take another scroll, and write all the earlier words on it that were on the first scroll, the one that Jehoiakim king of Judah burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Concerning Jehoiakim king of Judah, say: This is what the Lord says. You yourself have burned this scroll. You asked, “Why did you write on it that the king of Babylon would certainly come and destroy the land and cut off both men and animals?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why the Lord says this about Jehoiakim king of Judah: He will have no one to sit on David’s throne. His dead body will be thrown out and exposed to the heat of the day and the frost of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish him, his offspring, and his servants for their guilt. I will bring on them and on everyone who lives in Jerusalem and the men of Judah every disaster I have pronounced against them, because they did not listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to his scribe Baruch son of Neriah, who wrote on it all the same words that had been on the scroll that Jehoiakim king of Judah burned in the fire. And many similar words were added to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, made Zedekiah son of Josiah king in place of Jehoiachin son of Jehoiakim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But neither Zedekiah nor his attendants nor the people of the land obeyed the word of the Lord that he spoke through the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, King Zedekiah sent Jehucal son of Shelemiah with Zephaniah son of Ma’aseiah, the priest, to the prophet Jeremiah to request, “Please pray to the Lord our God for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah was still moving about freely among the people, for they had not yet put him into prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s army had come out of Egypt, and when the Chaldeans who were besieging Jerusalem heard the report about them, they withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord, the God of Israel, says to tell this to the king of Judah, who sent you to me to inquire of me. Be warned. Pharaoh’s army, which has come out to help you, will go back to Egypt, to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Chaldeans will return and attack this city. They will capture it and burn it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord says: “Do not deceive yourselves by saying, ‘The Chaldeans will surely leave us.’ They will not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For even if you would defeat the whole Chaldean army attacking you, and there were only wounded men left who were confined to their tents, they would still get up and burn this city down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Chaldean army had withdrawn from Jerusalem to face Pharaoh’s army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah left Jerusalem to go to the territory of Benjamin to claim his share of the property among the people there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as he arrived at the Benjamin Gate, the sentry who was in charge there, named Irijah son of Shelemiah, son of Hananiah, seized Jeremiah the prophet. He said, “You are deserting to the Chaldeans!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Jeremiah said, “That is false! I am not deserting to the Chaldeans.”
But Irijah did not listen to him. He seized Jeremiah and brought him to the officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Angry with Jeremiah, they beat him, and they imprisoned him in the house of Jonathan the scribe, because they were using that house as a prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah was kept in a vaulted cistern for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King Zedekiah sent for him and had him brought out. The king asked him secretly in his house, “Is there any word from the Lord?”
Jeremiah answered, “There is. He said, ‘You will be delivered into the hands of the king of Babylon.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah also said to King Zedekiah, “How have I sinned against you, against your servants, or against this people, that you have put me in prison?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are your prophets now, who prophesied to you, ‘The king of Babylon will not attack you or this land’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, my lord the king, please listen to me. Let my petition come before you: Please do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the scribe, or I will die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah the king ordered that Jeremiah be placed in the courtyard of the guard. Every day they gave him a loaf of bread from the street of the bakers until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shephatiah son of Mattah, Gedaliah son of Pashhur, Jehucal son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur son of Malkijah heard what Jeremiah had told the people when he said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says. Whoever remains in this city will die by sword, famine, and plague, but whoever goes over to the Chaldeans will live. He will escape with his life, and he will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. This city will surely be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon, and he will capture it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials said to the king, “This man should be put to death because he is demoralizing the soldiers who are left in the city. He is demoralizing all the people by saying these things to them. This man is not seeking the welfare of the people. He wants to hurt them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah answered, “Very well. He is in your hands. The king cannot do anything to stop you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took Jeremiah and threw him into the cistern of Malkijah, the king’s son, which was in the courtyard of the guard. They let Jeremiah down by ropes. There was no water in the cistern, but only mud, and Jeremiah sank down into the mud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed Melek the Cushite, an official in the king’s house, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the cistern. While the king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed Melek left the palace and said to the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My lord the king, everything that these men have done to Jeremiah the prophet is evil. They have thrown him into a cistern, where he is likely to die because of the famine, for there is no more bread in the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king gave orders to Ebed Melek the Cushite: “Take thirty men from here under your command and lift Jeremiah the prophet up out of the cistern before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ebed Melek took command of the men and entered a room under the treasury in the palace. He took some old rags and worn-out clothing from there, and he lowered them with ropes to Jeremiah in the cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed Melek the Cushite said to Jeremiah, “Put these rags and worn-out clothes under your arms to pad the ropes.” After Jeremiah did that,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they lifted him up with the ropes and pulled him out of the cistern. After this Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah then sent for Jeremiah and brought him to the third entrance of the temple of the Lord. He said to Jeremiah, “I am going to ask you something. Do not hide anything from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah replied, “Won’t you put me to death if I tell you the truth? If I give you advice, you won’t listen to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Zedekiah swore a secret oath to Jeremiah: “As surely as the Lord lives, who gave us our lives, I will not put you to death, and I will not hand you over to the men who seek your life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “The Lord, the God of Armies, the God of Israel, says: If you surrender to the Babylonian king’s officials, your life will be spared, and this city will not be burned. You will live, and your family will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you will not surrender to the Babylonian king’s officials, then this city will be handed over to the Chaldeans. They will burn it down, and you will not escape from their hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “I am afraid of the Jews who have defected to the Chaldeans. The Chaldeans may turn me over to them, and they will torture me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeremiah said, “They will not turn you over to them. Please obey the Lord by doing what I tell you. It will go well with you, and your life will be spared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the Lord has revealed to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the women who are left in the palace of the king of Judah will certainly be brought out to the officials of the Babylonian king. Those women will say to you, ‘Those trusted friends of yours misled you and led you to defeat. Your feet have sunk down into the mud, and they all have deserted you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will bring all your wives and children to the Chaldeans. You yourself will not escape their grasp. You will be seized by the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “If you do not let anyone know about this conversation, you will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the officials hear that I have spoken with you, they will come and ask you, ‘Tell us what you said to the king. Do not hide it from us, and we will not put you to death—just tell us what the king said to you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell them, ‘I was humbly begging the king not to return me to the house of Jonathan to die there.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials then came to Jeremiah. When they began to question him, he said everything just the way the king had commanded. Then they stopped questioning him, since no one had heard the conversation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard until the day Jerusalem was captured. He was still there when Jerusalem fell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the ninth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, in the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came to Jerusalem with his whole army and laid siege to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, on the ninth day of the month, a breach was made in the city wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officers of the king of Babylon entered and sat down in the middle gate: Nergal Sharezer the staff officer, Nebo Sarsekim a chief officer, Nergal Sharezer a high official, and all the other officials of the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zedekiah king of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled and left the city at night by way of the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls. Then they went toward the Arabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Chaldean army pursued them and overtook Zedekiah in the plains by Jericho. After they had captured him, they brought him up to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath and passed judgment on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon killed Zedekiah’s sons in front of his eyes at Riblah, and he also killed the nobles of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he put out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him with bronze shackles and sent him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldeans burned down the king’s palace and the houses of the people. They also broke down the walls of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, carried into exile the rest of the people who remained in the city, along with those who had deserted, as well as the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, left behind in the land of Judah some of the poor people, who owned nothing, and he then gave them vineyards and fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon gave orders to Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, concerning Jeremiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take him, look after him, and do him no harm. Do for him whatever he wants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard, Nebushazban the chief officer, Nergal Sharezer a high official, and all the other officials of the king of Babylon
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: sent for Jeremiah and had him taken out of the courtyard of the guard. They entrusted him to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, to take him to his house. So he remained among his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jeremiah had still been imprisoned in the courtyard of the guard, the word of the Lord had come to him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell Ebed Melek the Cushite that this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. Watch, I am going to fulfill my words against this city for evil and not for good. They are going to be fulfilled before your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will deliver you on that day, declares the Lord, and you will not be handed over to those you fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will certainly save you. You will not fall by the sword. You will escape with your life, because you have put your trust in me, declares the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had released him at Ramah. Jeremiah had been captured and bound in chains with all the captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were being carried into exile in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the captain of the guard found Jeremiah, he said to him, “The Lord your God pronounced this disaster on this place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord has brought it about and has done what he said he would do. This took place because you people sinned against the Lord and did not obey him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, today, I am removing the chains from your wrists. If you wish, come with me to Babylon. I will take care of you. But if this does not seem good to you, then don’t come. The whole land is before you. If there is a place that seems good and right to you, go there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But before Jeremiah turned away, he added, “Or you can go to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan. The king of Babylon has made him governor over the cities of Judah. You can live with him among the people. Go wherever it seems right for you to go.”
Then the commander of the guard gave him a gift and some food and released him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah went to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah and lived with him among the people who had been left behind in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the army officers who were still in the field and all their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam to be governor of the land, and that he had given him authority over the men, women, children, and over the poorest people of the land—those who were not carried away into exile in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They and their men went to Gedaliah at Mizpah—Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan and Jonathan the sons of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Ja’azaniah the son of the Ma’acathite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, swore an oath in the presence of them and their men. He said, “Do not be afraid of the Chaldeans. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, I will certainly stay at Mizpah to represent you before the Chaldeans who come to us. As for you, store up wine, summer fruit, and oil, put it into your jars, and live in the towns you have taken over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the Jews who were in Moab, among the Ammonites, in Edom, and in other lands heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant in Judah, and that he had appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, over them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all those Jews returned from all the places they had been scattered. They returned to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah at Mizpah. There they stored up a large amount of wine and summer fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah and the army officers who were still in the field came to Gedaliah at Mizpah
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to him, “Do you know that Baalis king of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to assassinate you?” But Gedaliah son of Ahikam did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah spoke secretly to Gedaliah at Mizpah, “I urge you, let me go and kill Ishmael son of Nethaniah. No one will know. Why should he assassinate you and cause all the Jews who are gathered around you to be scattered and the remnant of Judah to perish?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Gedaliah son of Ahikam said to Johanan son of Kareah, “Do not do this! What you are saying about Ishmael is false.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, a descendant of the royal family and one of the chief officers of the king, came with ten men to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah. While they were eating a meal together there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael son of Nethaniah got up and struck down Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, with a sword, killing the man the king of Babylon had appointed as governor over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael also struck down all the Jews who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah and also the Chaldean soldiers they found there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, the day after Gedaliah was assassinated, before anyone knew about it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: men came from Shechem, from Shiloh, and from Samaria—eighty men in all—with their beards shaved, their clothing torn, and their bodies gashed. They came bringing grain offerings and incense to the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael son of Nethaniah went out from Mizpah to meet them, weeping as he came. As he met them he said, “Come to Gedaliah son of Ahikam.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they got to the middle of the city, Ishmael son of Nethaniah and the men with him began to kill them, throwing their bodies into a cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But ten of them said to Ishmael, “Don’t kill us! We have food hidden in the countryside: wheat, barley, oil, and honey!”
So he stopped and did not murder them along with the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the cistern into which Ishmael threw all the dead bodies of the murdered men was a large one, which had been built by King Asa to defend against Ba’asha king of Israel. Ishmael son of Nethaniah filled it with the murdered men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ishmael made prisoners of all the people who were left in Mizpah, including the king’s daughters and the others who were left there in Mizpah—people whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had placed under the care of Gedaliah son of Ahikam. Ishmael son of Nethaniah took them as prisoners and set out to cross over to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers with him heard about all the crimes that Ishmael son of Nethaniah had committed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they took all of their men and went to attack Ishmael son of Nethaniah. They caught up with him by the great pool at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people with Ishmael saw Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers who were with him, they were glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of the people whom Ishmael had taken prisoner turned back and went to Johanan son of Kareah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ishmael son of Nethaniah and eight of his men escaped from Johanan and went over to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Johanan son of Kareah and the army officers with him took all the survivors from Mizpah, whom he had recovered from Ishmael son of Nethaniah after Ishmael had killed Gedaliah son of Ahikam—the soldiers, the women, the children, and the court officials that Johanan had brought back from Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They left there and stayed at Geruth Kimham near Bethlehem. They were on the way to Egypt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they were afraid of the Chaldeans, since Ishmael son of Nethaniah had killed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon had appointed as governor over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the army officers, including Johanan son of Kareah and Jezaniah son of Hoshaiah, and all the people from the least to the greatest approached Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “Please hear our request and pray to the Lord your God for us, for this group of survivors. As you can see, only a few of us are left, though once there were many.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray that the Lord your God may show us the way we should go and what we should do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah the prophet said to them, “I have heard you. Certainly, I will pray to the Lord your God as you have asked. I will tell you whatever the Lord answers. I will keep nothing back from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to Jeremiah, “May the Lord be a true and faithful witness against us if we do not do everything the Lord your God directs you to tell us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whether it is good or bad, we will obey the voice of the Lord our God, of whom you are inquiring for us. May it go well with us when we obey the voice of the Lord our God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten days later, the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers with him, along with all of the people from the least to the greatest,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and he reported this to them:
The Lord, the God of Israel, to whom you sent me to present your request, says this:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you stay in this land, I will build you up and not tear you down. I will plant you and not uproot you, for I am grieving over the disaster I brought upon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be afraid of the king of Babylon, whom you now fear. Do not be afraid of him, declares the Lord, for I am with you to save you and to deliver you from his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be merciful to you so that he will be merciful to you and will send you back to your own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you say, “We will not remain in this land,” and if you disobey the voice of the Lord your God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if you say, “No, we will go into the land of Egypt, where we will see no war, hear no battle signal from the ram’s horn, and experience no hunger for bread, and we will live there,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear the word of the Lord, you survivors from Judah. This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. If you are determined to go and live in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the sword you fear will overtake you in Egypt, the famine you dread will follow you there in Egypt, and you will die there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what will happen to everyone who is determined to go into Egypt. All of them will die by the sword, famine, and plague. None of them will survive or escape from the disaster I am going to bring on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. As my anger and my wrath have been poured out on those who live in Jerusalem, so will my wrath be poured out on you when you go to Egypt. You will be an object of horror and derision, an object of cursing and ridicule. You will never see this place again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says concerning you, you remaining survivors from Judah: Do not go to Egypt. You can be certain about this. I am warning you today
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you have put your own souls in danger by sending me to the Lord your God and saying, “Pray to the Lord our God for us. Tell us everything the Lord our God says, and we will do it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have told you this today, but you have not obeyed the voice of the Lord your God in anything he sent me to tell you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, be certain about this. You will die by the sword, famine, and plague in the place where you want to go and live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeremiah finished telling the people all the words of the Lord their God (everything the Lord had sent him to tell them),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah son of Hoshaiah, Johanan son of Kareah, and all the arrogant men said to Jeremiah, “You are lying. The Lord our God did not send you to tell us, ‘Do not go to Egypt to settle there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch son of Neriah has turned you against us, in order to hand us over to the Chaldeans, so that they may kill us or carry us away to Babylon as captives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers disobeyed the voice of the Lord, who was commanding them to remain in the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers took away everyone who remained in Judah, everyone who had returned to live in the land of Judah from the nations where they had been driven:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the men, women, and children, the king’s daughters, and everyone else that Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had left with Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, and also Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch son of Neriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They entered the land of Egypt, disobeying the voice of the Lord, and they went as far as Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Tahpanhes the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah. The Lord said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take some large stones in your hand while the men of Judah are watching, and bury them in the mudbrick pavement at the entrance of Pharaoh’s palace at Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell them that this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. Be sure of this. I will send for my servant, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and I will set his throne on these stones that I have hidden, and he will spread his royal canopy over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will come and attack Egypt, bringing death to those doomed to death, captivity to those doomed to captivity, and the sword to those doomed to the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will set fire to the temples of the gods of Egypt. He will burn them—or carry them away to captivity. He will wrap Egypt around himself as a shepherd wraps a cloak around himself. Then he will go away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will smash the sacred obelisks in the temple of the sun in the land of Egypt, and he will burn down the temples of the Egyptian gods.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews who lived in the land of Egypt—in Migdol, Tahpanhes, and Memphis, and also in Upper Egypt:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says. You have seen the disaster I brought on Jerusalem and all the cities of Judah. You see that today they are desolate and no one lives there
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they committed evil and provoked me to anger. They burned incense to serve other gods that neither they, nor you, nor your fathers knew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I kept sending my servants the prophets to you again and again, saying, “Do not do this detestable thing that I hate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they did not listen or pay attention. They did not turn away from their wickedness or stop burning incense to other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, my wrath and anger were poured out and ignited against the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, and they were laid waste and desolate, as they are this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord, the God of Armies, the God of Israel, says. Why are you doing such an evil thing to yourselves? You are cutting off from Judah man and woman, children and infants, leaving no one remaining.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why are you provoking me to anger with the idols your hands have made? Why are you burning incense to other gods in Egypt where you have gone to live? You will cut yourselves off, making yourselves an object of cursing and ridicule among all the nations of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten the wickedness of your fathers, the wickedness of the king of Judah, the wickedness of their wives, your own wickedness, and the wickedness of your wives in the land of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have not humbled themselves even to this day. They have not feared me or walked in my law or in my statutes that I set before you and your fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I will certainly set my face against you to bring disaster, to cut off all Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will remove the survivors of Judah who are determined to go to Egypt and settle there, and they will be consumed. In the land of Egypt they will fall. They will be consumed by sword and famine. They will die, from the least to the greatest, by sword and famine. They will become an object of horror and derision, an object of cursing and ridicule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish those who go to live in the land of Egypt as I punished Jerusalem—with the sword, famine, and plague—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that none of the survivors of Judah who have gone to live in Egypt will escape or survive to return to the land of Judah, to which they long to return in order to live there, because none of them will return, except a few refugees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men who knew that their wives were burning incense to other gods, and all the women who were standing there—a large crowd—and all the people living in Lower Egypt and Upper Egypt answered Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We will not listen to the message you have spoken to us in the name of the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but instead we will continue doing everything that we said we would do. We will burn incense to the Queen of Heaven, and we will pour out drink offerings to her, just as we and our ancestors, our kings, and our officials used to do in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. Then we had plenty of food. We were prosperous, and we had no troubles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But ever since we stopped burning incense to the Queen of Heaven and stopped pouring out drink offerings to her, we have had nothing at all, and we have been consumed by sword and famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the women said, “When we burned incense to the Queen of Heaven and poured out drink offerings to her, did we make the cakes in her image and pour out drink offerings to her without our husbands’ approval?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, both men and women, who were answering him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you think the Lord did not remember the incense you burned in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem—you, your ancestors, your kings and officials, and the people of the land? Do you think this did not enter his mind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord could no longer bear your evil acts and the disgusting things you did, your land became a desolate wasteland, a cursed land, with no one living there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is because you have burned incense and sinned against the Lord, because you have not obeyed him or walked in his law, his statutes, and his decrees, that this disaster has come upon you now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah then said to all the people, including the women, “Hear the word of the Lord, all you people of Judah in Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says this. You and your wives have declared with your words and your actions that you will keep the vows you made to burn incense to the Queen of Heaven and to pour out drink offerings to her. Do what you promised! By all means, fulfill your vows!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But hear the word of the Lord, all you Jews living in Egypt. Listen! I swear by my great name, declares the Lord, that my name will no longer be spoken by anyone from Judah living anywhere in Egypt, nor will they swear, “As surely as the Lord God lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look at this! I am watching over them to bring disaster, not good, and all the men of Judah who are in the land of Egypt will be consumed by sword and famine until they are all gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who escape the sword and return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah will be very few. Then all the remnant of Judah who entered Egypt to live there will know whose word will stand—mine or theirs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will be a sign to you, declares the Lord. I will punish you in this place. Then you will know that my warnings to bring disaster upon you will stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. Watch me. I am handing Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, over to his enemies who seek his life, just as I handed Zedekiah king of Judah over to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, the enemy who sought his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that Jeremiah the prophet gave to Baruch son of Neriah when he was writing down on a scroll the words that Jeremiah was dictating. This was in the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says to you, Baruch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said, “Woe is me! The Lord has added sorrow to my pain. I am worn out with groaning and I have found no rest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. Tell him that I will overthrow what I have built and uproot what I have planted throughout the whole world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So should you then be seeking great things for yourself? Stop seeking them. I will certainly bring disaster on every living thing, declares the Lord. But in every place you go, I will let you hang on to your life like a prize of war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the nations:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Egypt:
Concerning the strong army of Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon defeated at Carchemish on the Euphrates River in the fourth year of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Arrange your shields, both large and small,
and march out for battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Harness the horses!
Mount up, you horsemen!
Take up your stations with your helmets on.
Polish your spears.
Put on your armor!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But what do I see?
They are terrified.
They are turning back.
Their warriors are beaten.
They are fleeing without looking back.
There is terror on every side! declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no chance for the swift to flee.
There is no escape for the strong.
In the north, near the River Euphrates,
they stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this, rising like the Nile,
like rivers with surging waters?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is Egypt that rises like the Nile,
like rivers with surging waters.
Egypt said, “I will rise.
I will cover the earth.
I will destroy cities
and those who live in them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Horses, charge!
Charioteers, drive like madmen!
Forward, you warriors,
you men of Cush and Put who carry the shield,
you men of Lud who grasp and bend the bow!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That day is the day of the Lord, the God of Armies.
It is a day of vengeance,
when he will take vengeance on his foes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go up to Gilead and get balm,
    virgin daughter of Egypt!
You have tried many medicines with no results.
There is no healing for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations have heard of your shame,
and your cry fills the earth.
Warrior stumbles against warrior,
and the two of them fall together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word the Lord spoke to Jeremiah the prophet about the coming of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to strike the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Declare this in Egypt. Proclaim it in Migdol.
Proclaim it in Memphis and Tahpanhes.
Say, “Take your positions and get ready.
The sword is going to devour those around you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why are your mighty ones laid low?
They cannot stand, for the Lord has pushed them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made many stumble.
They fall against each other.
They say, “Get up! Let’s go back to our people
and to the land of our birth,
away from the sword of our oppressor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There they will cry out,
“Pharaoh king of Egypt is only a loud noise.
He has missed his opportunity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As surely as I live, declares the King,
whose name is the Lord of Armies,
someone is coming who is like Tabor among the mountains,
and like Carmel by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get your bags ready to go into exile,
    you daughter who dwells in Egypt,
for Memphis will become a desolation
and lie in ruins without an inhabitant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt is a lovely heifer,
but a horsefly has come against her out of the north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mercenaries in her ranks are like fattened calves.
They will turn and flee together.
They will not stand,
for the day of disaster has come upon them,
the time for their punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt will hiss like a snake,
because the enemy will advance as an army.
It will come against her with axes,
like men who cut down trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will cut down her forest, declares the Lord,
though it is impenetrable,
even though they are more numerous than locusts,
even though they are too many to count.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The daughter of Egypt will be put to shame,
handed over to the people from the north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Watch, I will punish Amon god of Thebes, along with Pharaoh, with Egypt, her gods, and her kings—Pharaoh and those who trust in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will hand them over to those who seek their lives, to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his officers.
But afterward Egypt will be inhabited as in former days, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But do not be afraid, my servant Jacob.
Do not be terrified, Israel,
because I will save you from a faraway place,
and I will rescue your descendants from the land where
        they are captives.
Jacob will return.
He will enjoy quiet and be at ease,
and no one will make him afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be afraid, my servant Jacob, declares the Lord,
for I am with you.
I will completely destroy all the nations
    among which I have scattered you,
but I will not completely destroy you.
I will discipline you with justice,
and I will not regard you as entirely innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the Philistines, before Pharaoh struck Gaza.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says.
See, waters rise up out of the north,
and they will become an overflowing stream.
They will overflow the land and everything in it,
the cities and those who live there.
The people will cry out,
and everyone who lives in the land will wail
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
at the sound of the stamping hoofs of his steeds,
    at the rumbling of his chariots,
    at the roar of his wheels.
Fathers will not turn back for their sons,
because their hands will hang limp,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
on account of the day that is coming to destroy all the Philistines,
to cut off from Tyre and Sidon every helper who survives.
For the Lord will destroy the Philistines,
the surviving remnant from the shores of Caphtor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Baldness is coming to Gaza.
Ashkelon will be destroyed.
You survivors left on the plain,
how long will you cut yourselves?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O sword of the Lord!
How long until you rest?
Return to your scabbard.
Rest and be still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How can you rest since the Lord has commanded this?
Against Ashkelon and against the shore of the sea,
        he has assigned the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says.
Woe to Nebo! It will be destroyed.
Kiriathaim will be disgraced and captured.
The stronghold will be disgraced and broken down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There will no longer be any praise for Moab.
They have plotted evil against her in Heshbon:
“Come, let us destroy that nation!”
You will be silenced, O Madmen.
The sword will pursue you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sound of a cry from Horonaim,
desolation and great destruction!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab is destroyed.
Her little ones will cry out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now they go up the ascent to Luhith,
    weeping continually.
And on the descent of Horonaim
they have heard the cry of distress
    caused by the destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee! Save your lives!
Be like a juniper bush in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because you trusted in your works and treasures,
you too will be taken.
Chemosh will go into exile,
together with his priests and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The destroyer will come against every city,
and no city will escape.
The valley will also perish,
and the tableland will be destroyed, as the Lord has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give Moab a blossom, but it will blow away completely.
Her cities will become desolate
with no one to live in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed is the one who is negligent in doing the Lord’s work.
Cursed is the one who holds back his sword from bloodshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab has been at peace since its youth,
undisturbed, like wine on its dregs,
never poured from one vessel to another.
It has never gone into captivity.
That is why it tastes the same as it always did,
and its aroma is unchanged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, know this: the days are coming, declares the Lord,
when I will send to Moab people who pour,
and they will pour it out.
They will drain its containers
and smash its jars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh,
as the house of Israel was ashamed of Bethel, in which they trusted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How can you say, “We are mighty warriors,
courageous soldiers?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab is laid waste,
and they have gone up into its cities.
Its finest young men have gone down to be slaughtered.
The declaration of the King,
whose name is the Lord of Armies:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The destruction of Moab is approaching,
and its disaster hurries swiftly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mourn for it, all you surrounding nations.
All you who know its name say,
“How the mighty scepter is broken,
the glorious staff!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come down from your glory,
and sit on the parched ground,
you who dwell in Dibon.
Moab’s destroyer has come up against you.
He has destroyed your strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stand beside the road and watch,
you who dwell in Aroer.
Ask him who flees, ask her who escapes,
“What has happened?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab is withered,
for it is broken down.
Wail and cry!
Tell it by the Arnon, that Moab has been destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judgment has come upon the tableland, on Holon, on Jahzah, on Mepha’ath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on Dibon, on Nebo, on Beth Diblathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on Kiriathaim, on Beth Gamul, on Beth Meon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on Kerioth, on Bozrah, and on all the towns of the land of Moab, far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The horn of Moab is cut off,
and his arm is broken, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make him drunk,
because he exalted himself against the Lord.
Moab will wallow in his vomit,
and he will be ridiculed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Was not Israel ridiculed by you?
Was Israel caught among thieves,
so that whenever you speak of him,
you shake your head?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live in Moab, abandon the cities and dwell in the rocks.
Be like a dove that makes her nest over the mouth of a chasm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have heard about the pride of Moab.
He is very arrogant.
He is smug, he is conceited,
he is proud, and his heart is haughty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know his insolence, says the Lord.
It is empty, and so are his deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore I will wail for Moab.
I will cry out for all of Moab.
I will mourn for the men of Kir Hareseth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will weep for you, vine of Sibmah,
more than Jazer.
Your branches passed over the sea.
They reached to the Sea of Jazer.
The destroyer has fallen on your summer fruit
and on your grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gladness and joy have been taken from the fertile field
and from the land of Moab.
I have stopped the flow of wine from the winepresses.
No one will tread them with shouts of joy.
The shouting is not shouting for joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is an outcry from Heshbon to Elealeh.
They raise their voices as far as Jahaz,
from Zoar to Horonaim and Eglath Shelishiyah,
and even the waters of Nimrim have dried up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In Moab, declares the Lord,
I will stop the one who presents offerings on the high places
and burns incense to his gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, my heart wails like a flute for Moab,
and for the men of Kir Hareseth my heart wails like a flute.
Even the wealth they have acquired is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every head is shaved, and every beard is clipped.
Every hand is cut, and there is sackcloth around their waists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On all the rooftops of Moab
and in its streets there is wailing,
because I have broken Moab like an unwanted jar,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How broken she is!
How they wail!
How Moab turns her back in shame!
So Moab will be ridiculed
and be a horror to all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the Lord says:
Watch, he will fly like an eagle,
and he will spread his wings against Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Kerioth is taken,
and the strongholds are seized.
On that day the hearts of Moab’s strong warriors
    will be like the heart of a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed as a nation
because he has defied the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Panic, pit, and peril are before you,
you who live in Moab, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever flees from the panic will fall into the pit.
Whoever gets out of the pit will be trapped in the snare,
for I will bring on Moab the year of their punishment,
says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who fled stand helpless under the shadow of Heshbon,
because a fire has gone out from Heshbon,
and a flame from the midst of Sihon.
It has burned the foreheads of Moab,
and the tops of the heads of those who boast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to you, O Moab!
The people of Chemosh are destroyed,
for your sons are taken away captive,
and your daughters go into exile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, I will reverse the captivity of Moab in days to come,
    declares the Lord.
This is the conclusion of the judgment against Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning the people of Ammon, this is what the Lord says:
Has Israel no sons?
Has he no heir?
Why then does Milcom possess Gad?
Why do his people live in Israel’s cities?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch, the days are coming, declares the Lord,
when I will sound a battle cry against Rabbah of the Ammonites,
and it will become a desolate heap.
Her villages will be burned down,
and then Israel will possess those who possessed him,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wail, Heshbon, for Ai is laid waste!
Cry, you daughters of Rabbah!
Put on sackcloth and mourn.
Run back and forth behind the walls,
because Milcom is about to go into captivity,
with his priests and his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you boast about your valleys,
your flowing valley, you backsliding daughter?
You trusted in your treasures, saying,
“Who will come against me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look out! I will bring terror upon you,
says the Lord God of Armies,
terror from every side.
All of you will be completely driven out,
and there will be no one to gather together the fugitives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But afterward I will restore the captives of the Ammonites,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Edom, this is what the Lord of Armies says:
Is there no more wisdom in Teman?
Has counsel perished from the prudent?
Has their wisdom vanished?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee! Turn back!
Dwell in the depths, you who live in Dedan,
for I will bring the disaster of Esau on him when I punish him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If grape pickers came to you,
wouldn’t they leave some grapes for gleaning?
If thieves came by night,
wouldn’t they stop when they had stolen enough?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I have stripped Esau bare.
I have uncovered his secret places,
and he will not be able to hide himself.
His offspring are destroyed,
along with his brothers and his neighbors,
and he is no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Leave your fatherless children.
I will preserve their lives.
Let your widows trust in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord says: If those who did not deserve to drink from the cup must drink it, will you escape unpunished? No, you will not remain unpunished. You must drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have sworn by myself, declares the Lord, that Bozrah will become a horror, a disgrace, ruins, and a curse. All its cities will be perpetual ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have heard news from the Lord,
and a messenger has been sent to the nations:
“Gather yourselves together,
and come against her!
Rise up for the battle!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, I have made you small among the nations
and despised among mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The terror you instill has deceived you,
the pride of your heart.
You who dwell in the clefts of the rock,
who occupy the high point of the hill,
even though you make your nest as high as the eagle’s nest,
I will bring you down from there, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Edom will become a horror.
Everyone who passes by it will be shocked,
and they will hiss because of all its disasters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As Sodom and Gomorrah
and their neighboring cities were overthrown,
says the Lord,
no one will live there.
Not one person will dwell in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch this.
Like a lion coming out of the thickets of the Jordan
    into the pastures that are always green,
I will suddenly chase Edom away from its land,
and I will appoint whomever I choose over it.
For who is like me?
Who can challenge me?
What shepherd can stand before me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, hear what the Lord has planned for Edom,
what he intends to do against the people of Teman.
Even the little ones of the flock will be dragged away.
He will make their pasture desolate because of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will tremble at the noise of their fall.
Their cry will be heard all the way to the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch, he will come up and fly like an eagle.
He will spread out his wings against Bozrah.
In that day the hearts of the strong warriors of Edom
    will be like the heart of a woman during her labor pains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Damascus:
Hamath and Arpad are troubled,
for they have heard bad news.
They melt in fear.
Like a troubled sea,
they cannot find rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Damascus has become feeble.
She turns to flee.
Panic has seized her.
Anguish and sorrows have taken hold of her,
    like those of a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why is this famous city not yet forsaken,
the joyful city?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, her young men will fall in her streets,
and all her warriors will be destroyed on that day,
declares the Lord of Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will set fire to the walls of Damascus,
and it will devour the citadels of Ben Hadad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor, which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon struck, this is what the Lord says:
Arise, go up to Kedar,
and destroy the people of the East.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their tents and their flocks will be taken,
their tent curtains and everything in their tents.
Their camels will be taken away from them,
and men will shout to them, “Terror on every side!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Quick, fly away!
Hide in deep caves, you who live in Hazor,
declares the Lord,
because Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has plotted against you,
and he has made plans to defeat you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Arise! Attack a nation at ease, that lives without care,
declares the Lord,
a nation that has neither gates nor bars, that lives by itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their camels will be plunder,
and their vast herds of livestock a prize.
I will scatter to all the winds those who live in distant places,
and I will bring disaster on them from every side,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hazor will be a place where jackals live,
a desolate place forever.
No man will live there.
No one will live in that place even as a temporary resident.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning Elam, early in the reign of Zedekiah king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says.
Look, I will break the bow of Elam,
the main source of its power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring against Elam the four winds,
from the four corners of the sky.
I will scatter its people to the four winds.
There will not be a nation
    where the outcasts of Elam do not go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make Elam terrified of their enemies,
those who seek their lives.
I will bring disaster on them,
namely, my fierce anger, declares the Lord,
and I will send the sword after them,
until I have consumed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will set up my throne in Elam,
and there I will destroy their king and officials,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet I will reverse the captivity of Elam in days to come,
declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word that the Lord spoke concerning Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans, through Jeremiah the prophet:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Declare and proclaim this among the nations.
Set up a signal flag.
Proclaim and do not hide it.
Say this:
Babylon has been taken.
Bel has been put to shame.
Marduk is terrified.
Babylon’s images have been put to shame.
Her filthy idols are terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A nation has come up against her out of the north.
It will make her land desolate,
and no one will dwell in it.
Both man and animal have wandered away.
They are gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days, and in that time, declares the Lord,
the people of Israel will come,
they and the people of Judah together with them.
They will come weeping,
and they will seek the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will ask the way to Zion and turn toward it,
saying, “Come, join yourselves to the Lord
    in an everlasting covenant that will not be forgotten.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people have been lost sheep.
Their shepherds have led them astray.
They have turned them aside on the mountains.
They have gone from mountain to hill.
They have forgotten their resting place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All who found them have devoured them.
Their enemies said, “We are not guilty,
because they sinned against the Lord,
who is their rightful pasture,
the Lord, the hope of their fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee from Babylon!
Leave the land of the Chaldeans.
Be like the male goats that lead the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch, I will stir up and bring against Babylon
    an assembly of great nations from the land of the north.
They will array themselves against her,
and she will be taken away captive from there.
Their arrows will be like those of a skilled warrior
    who does not return empty-handed.
verses.speaker: Narrator
