verses.text:
Chaldea will be plundered.
All who prey on her will have their fill, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because you are glad and rejoice,
you who plunder my inheritance,
because you leap like a heifer that treads out the grain,
and you neigh like strong horses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
your mother will be completely put to shame.
She who gave birth to you will be humiliated.
Watch, she will become the least of the nations,
a wilderness, a desert, a wasteland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of the Lord’s wrath she will not be inhabited.
She will be completely desolate.
Everyone who passes by Babylon will be astonished.
Everyone will mock her because of all her wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Line up for battle against Babylon and surround her.
All you who bend the bow, shoot at her.
Don’t save any arrows,
because she has sinned against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shout against her from all sides.
She surrenders!
Her fortifications have fallen.
Her walls have been thrown down.
This is the vengeance of the Lord.
Take vengeance on her!
Do to her as she has done to others!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cut off the sower from Babylon,
and the one who swings the sickle at harvest time.
They will each return to their own people.
They will each flee to their own land
    because they fear the sword of the oppressor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Israel is a scattered flock of sheep that lions have chased away.
First, the king of Assyria devoured him.
Now, the last to crush his bones was Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says:
I will certainly punish the king of Babylon and his land,
as I punished the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will restore Israel to his pasture.
He will feed on Carmel and in Bashan.
His soul will be satisfied on the hills of Ephraim and Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days and at that time, declares the Lord,
the guilt of Israel will be sought,
but there will be none.
The sins of Judah will be sought,
but they will not be found,
for I will forgive the survivors whom I spare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go up against the land of Merathaim
and against those who live in Pekod.
Kill them and destroy them, declares the Lord.
Do everything I have commanded you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The noise of battle is in the land,
the noise of great destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the hammer of the whole earth
    is smashed and broken to pieces!
How Babylon has become a horror among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I set a trap for you, Babylon,
and you were caught before you knew it.
You were found and captured,
because you fought against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has opened his arsenal
and brought out his weapons of wrath,
for the Lord God of Armies has work to do
    in the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come against her from far away.
Open up her granaries,
and pile her up like heaps of grain.
Destroy her completely.
Let nothing be left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Kill all her young bulls.
Let them go down to the slaughter.
Woe to them, for their day has come,
the time for their punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the fugitives and refugees from Babylon!
They proclaim in Zion the vengeance of the Lord our God,
vengeance for what was done to his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Call the archers to Babylon,
all those who bend the bow.
Set up camp all around her.
Don’t let her escape.
Pay her back for her deeds.
Do to her what she has done,
because she has defied the Lord,
the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore her young men will fall in the streets.
All her soldiers will be silenced in that day, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, I am against you, you proud one, declares the Lord God of Armies.
Your day has come,
the time for your punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The proud king will stumble and fall,
and no one will help him up.
In his cities I will start a fire
    that will consume everyone around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says.
The children of Israel and the children of Judah are oppressed.
All their captors hold them fast.
They refuse to let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But their Redeemer is strong.
The Lord of Armies is his name.
He himself will take up their cause
    so that he may bring rest to the earth,
    and unrest to those who live in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against the Chaldeans, declares the Lord,
and against those who live in Babylon,
against her officials and her wise men!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against her empty boasters!
They will become fools.
A sword against her strong warriors!
They will be filled with terror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against their horses and chariots!
All the foreigners in her ranks will become as weak as women.
A sword against her treasures!
They will be looted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against her waters!
They will be dried up,
because it is a land of idols,
and they are driven mad by those dreadful images.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why desert animals and hyenas will live there,
and shrieking ostriches will dwell there.
It will never again be inhabited.
It will never be lived in from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah
and their neighboring cities, declares the Lord,
no one will dwell there.
No one will live there even as a temporary resident.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! A people comes from the north!
A great nation and many kings are being stirred up
    from the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They take up bow and spear.
They are cruel and merciless.
Their roar sounds like the sea.
They ride on horses,
arrayed in battle formation against you, daughter of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Babylon has heard the report about them,
and his hands hang limp.
Anguish grips him,
pains like a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch this!
Like a lion coming out of the thickets of the Jordan
    into the pastures that are always green,
I will suddenly chase Babylon away from its land,
and I will appoint whomever I choose over it.
For who is like me?
Who can challenge me?
    What shepherd can stand before me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore hear what the Lord has planned for Babylon,
and what he intends to do against the land of the Chaldeans:
Even the little ones of the flock will be dragged away.
He will make their pasture desolate because of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will tremble at the noise of Babylon’s fall.
Their cry will be heard among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
Watch, I will stir up a destroying wind against Babylon
and against the people who live in Leb Kamai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will send foreigners to Babylon
    to winnow her and empty her land.
They will oppose her on every side in the day of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bend your bow against anyone who bends a bow
and against anyone who stands in armor.
Do not spare the young men.
Completely destroy her army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They fall down, slain in the land of Chaldea,
mortally wounded in her streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Israel and Judah are not forsaken by God, the Lord of Armies,
though their land is full of guilt before the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee from the midst of Babylon!
Everyone, save your lives!
Do not be cut off because of her guilt,
for it is the time for the Lord’s vengeance.
He will punish them as they deserve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon was a golden cup in the Lord’s hand.
She made the whole world drunk.
The nations have drunk her wine,
and now they have gone mad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Suddenly Babylon has fallen and is broken.
Wail for her.
Take balm to her for her pain.
Perhaps she can be healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We would have healed Babylon,
but she cannot be healed.
Leave her! Everyone go to his own land,
because her judgment reaches to the heavens.
It rises up to the clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has brought our vindication.
Come, let us declare in Zion what the Lord our God has done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sharpen the arrows!
Hang on to the shields!
The Lord has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes,
because his purpose is to destroy Babylon.
This is the vengeance of the Lord,
vengeance for his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Raise a signal flag against the walls of Babylon!
Strengthen the guard!
Set the watch,
and prepare an ambush!
The Lord has done what he said he would do
    against the inhabitants of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live by many waters,
you who are rich in treasures,
your end has come,
the full measure of your violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord of Armies has sworn by himself:
Surely I will fill you with men,
as if I were filling you with locusts.
They will raise the shout of victory over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is the One who made the earth by his power
and established the world by his wisdom.
By his understanding he stretched out the heavens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He thunders, and the waters in the heavens roar.
He makes storm clouds rise from the ends of the earth.
He makes lightning for the rain,
and he brings the wind out from his warehouses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But as for mankind, they are all stupid.
Their knowledge has dried up.
Every goldsmith is embarrassed by his idols.
The images he makes are false.
There is no breath in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are worthless,
an achievement to be mocked.
At the time of their punishment, they will perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who is the Portion of Jacob is not like these,
because he is the Maker of all things,
including the tribe that is his possession.
The Lord of Armies is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are my hammer, my war weapon.
With you I shatter nations.
With you I destroy kingdoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With you I shatter horse and rider.
With you I shatter chariot and driver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With you I shatter man and woman.
With you I shatter the old and the young.
With you I shatter the young man and the virgin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With you I shatter the shepherd and his flock.
With you I shatter the plowman and the team in his yoke.
With you I shatter governors and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before your very eyes I will repay Babylon and everyone who lives in Chaldea for all the evil they have done in Zion, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, I am against you, declares the Lord.
You destroying mountain,
you destroy the whole world.
I will stretch out my hand against you.
I will roll you off the cliffs,
and I will make you a burned-out volcano.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No rock will be taken from you for a cornerstone,
nor as a foundation stone.
You will be desolate forever, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Raise a signal flag in the land!
Blow the ram’s horn among the nations!
Set apart the nations against her!
Call together against her the kingdoms of Ararat,
    Minni, and Ashkenaz!
Appoint a field marshal against her!
Bring up horses like a thick swarm of locusts!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consecrate the nations against her—
the kings of the Medes, their governors, all their officials,
and all the land under their dominion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The land trembles and writhes
because the Lord’s intentions against Babylon stand.
He will make the land of Babylon a desolation with no one living there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The strong warriors of Babylon have stopped fighting.
They stay in their strongholds.
Their power has failed.
They have become as weak as women.
Her dwellings are set on fire.
The bars of the gates are broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Runner follows runner,
and messenger follows messenger
    to announce to the king of Babylon
    that his city is taken in every quarter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fords have been captured,
the marshes are on fire,
and the soldiers are in a panic.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says.
The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor when it is trampled.
In just a little while, the time of her harvest will come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon has devoured us.
He has crushed us
and made us like an empty jar.
Like a monster, he has swallowed us,
filled his stomach with our tastiest parts,
and spit out the rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“May the violence done to us and to our children be upon Babylon,”
says she who dwells in Zion.
“May our blood be on those who live in Chaldea,” says Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore this is what the Lord says:
Watch! I will defend your cause
and take revenge for you.
I will dry up her sea
and make her springs dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon will become a heap of ruins,
a haunt for jackals,
a horror and a target of contempt,
and no one will live there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will all roar together like young lions.
They will growl like lion cubs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they are ravenous, I will spread a feast.
I will make them drunk,
so that they will celebrate,
and then they will go to sleep forever
and never wake up, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter,
like rams and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How Sheshak is captured!
The pride of the whole earth is seized!
Babylon has become an object of horror among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sea has come all the way up to Babylon,
and she is covered with its rolling waves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her cities have become desolate,
a desert and a wasteland,
a land in which no one lives,
a land through which no man passes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will punish Bel in Babylon
and make his mouth spit out what he has swallowed.
The nations will no longer stream to him.
The wall of Babylon will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come out of her, my people!
Save yourselves, every one of you,
    from the Lord’s fierce anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be faint of heart.
Do not fear the rumors you will hear in the land.
Rumors will come one year,
and the next year another rumor will come:
“Violence in the land!”
“Ruler against ruler!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the days are coming when I will punish the idols of Babylon.
Her whole land will be disgraced,
and all her slain will fall within her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the heavens and the earth and all that is in them
    will rejoice over Babylon.
The destroyers will attack her from the north, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon must fall because of Israel’s slain,
just as the slain in all the earth have fallen because of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who have escaped the sword, go!
Do not delay!
Remember the Lord from afar,
and think of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We are disgraced,
because we have heard a taunt.
Dishonor covers our faces,
because strangers have come into the holy places of
        the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So keep watch. The days are coming, declares the Lord,
when I will punish all her idols.
Through her whole land the wounded will groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if Babylon could reach the sky
and fortify the very heights of her stronghold,
I would still send destroyers to her, declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sound of a cry comes from Babylon,
the sound of great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is destroying Babylon,
and he will silence her mighty voice.
Waves roar like many waters.
The sound of their noise rises!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The destroyer has come against her, against Babylon.
Her mighty warriors are captured.
Their bows are broken,
for the Lord is a God of retribution.
He will repay in full.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make her officials and her wise men drunk,
and her governors, officers, and strong warriors as well.
They will sleep for a long time,
and they will not wake up,
declares the King, whose name is the Lord of Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says.
The thick walls of Babylon will be leveled,
and her high gates will be set on fire.
The people will toil for nothing.
The work of the nations will be nothing but fuel for the fire.
They will be worn out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the instructions Jeremiah the prophet gave to Seraiah son of Neriah, the son of Mahseiah, when he went with Zedekiah king of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. (Seraiah was Zedekiah’s personal aide.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah had written on a scroll about all the disaster that was coming to Babylon—all of these things that had been written about Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said to Seraiah, “When you get to Babylon, see to it that you read all these words aloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say, ‘O Lord, you have spoken against this place, announcing that you would destroy it, that no one will live here anymore, neither man nor animal, and that it will be desolate forever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you finish reading this book, tie a stone to it and throw it in the middle of the Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then say, ‘In this same way, Babylon will sink and never rise again, because of the disaster that I will bring on her. And her people will be worn out.’”
The words of Jeremiah end here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king. He ruled in Jerusalem for eleven years. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah from Libnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, just like everything that Jehoiakim had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All this took place in Jerusalem and Judah because of the anger of the Lord, until he cast them out of his presence.
Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the ninth year of Zedekiah’s reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came against Jerusalem with his whole army. They set up camp around the city and built siege works all around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city was under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine was so severe in the city that there was no bread for the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a breach was made in the city wall, and all the men in the army fled. Since the Chaldeans had surrounded the city, the men left it at night by way of the gate between the two walls near the king’s garden. They fled toward the Arabah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the Chaldean army pursued the king. They caught up with King Zedekiah in the plain near Jericho, where his whole army was scattered,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he was captured and taken to the king of Babylon at Riblah in Hamath. There the king of Babylon passed judgment on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons before his eyes. He also slaughtered all the officials of Judah at Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Babylon put out the eyes of Zedekiah and put him in bronze shackles. He brought him to Babylon and put him in prison until the day he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the tenth day of the fifth month, in the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard who served the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the temple of the Lord, the king’s palace, and all the houses of Jerusalem. He burned down every important building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole Chaldean army under his command broke down all the walls around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried off some of the poorest of the people, some of the survivors left in the city, some of the people who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the craftsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to work the vineyards and farms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldeans broke up the bronze pillars that were in the Lord’s temple, along with the carts for water and the bronze Sea, and carried away all the bronze to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also took away the pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the bowls, the dishes, and all the bronze articles used in the temple service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander of the guard took away the bowls, fire pans, sprinkling bowls, pots, lampstands, dishes, and the drink offering bowls—the best of the gold and the best of the silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two pillars, the Sea, and the twelve bronze bulls under the basins, which King Solomon had made for the temple of the Lord, were made of more bronze than could be weighed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the pillars, each pillar was twenty-seven feet high and eighteen feet in circumference. Each was four fingers thick and hollow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each had a bronze capital, seven and a half feet high, with a network and pomegranate decorations on the capital all around, all of bronze. The other pillar with its pomegranates was just like it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides. There was a total of one hundred pomegranates above the surrounding network.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three doorkeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the people left in the city, he took the officer in charge of the fighting men and seven royal advisors he found in the city. He also took the scribe of the military officer who conscripted the people of the land, along with sixty of his men who were found in the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Babylon struck them down and executed them at Riblah in the land of Hamath.
So Judah was carried away into exile from its native soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is a tally of people whom Nebuchadnezzar carried away into exile:
In the seventh year, 3,023 Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar, 832 people from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the twenty-third year of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried away 745 Jews into exile.
There were 4,600 people in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the first year of the reign of Evil Merodak king of Babylon, he elevated Jehoiachin king of Judah and released him from prison on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke kindly to him and gave him a throne higher than the thrones of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiachin changed from his prison clothes and ate his meals in the king’s presence continually all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For his provisions, a regular allowance was given to him by the king of Babylon, a set amount each day until the day of his death, all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator
